Award.AwardTitle: The functional organization of an eye with bifocal lens.
Award.AbstractNarration: Almost all animal eyes follow a few and relatively well-understood functional plans. Only rarely is an eye discovered that diverges fundamentally from known types, yet such exceptions frequently lead to exciting new discoveries in visual system function. The principal eyes of the Sunburst Diving Beetle larvae (Thermonectus marmoratus) are among the most bizarre and strangely organized eyes in the animal kingdom, yet the larvae are extremely successful at capturing prey. How does the unorthodox visual system facilitate efficient prey capture? Anatomically, the eyes are characterized by multiple layered retinas, one of which is sensitive to green light whereas a second, deeper retina is sensitive to UV light. It was recently discovered that this visual system operates with truly bifocal lenses, an organization never before demonstrated in an animal; this finding leads to the possibility that each retina receives its own sharp image. Moreover it has become clear that these bifocal lenses use an interesting optical asymmetry that allows the animal to see each of the two images more clearly. This project will use histological and optical techniques to investigate the physical and optical organization of lenses and will use physiological measurements to determine how light excites individual photoreceptors. Throughout the project, several undergraduate and graduate students will be trained, and outreach activities will include science experiments at local schools. A broader impact on the society at large is expected from a better understanding of the design principles of these bifocal lenses, principles that potentially could lead to improved designs of commercial bifocal and multifocal systems and the development of novel materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal eyes of the Sunburst Diving Beetle (Thermonectus marmoratus) larvae (Figure 1) are among the most bizarre and strangely organized eyes in the animal kingdom, and it has become clear that the eyes are extremely important for these larvae to be able to catch prey within their often murky aquatic environment.  These larvae are extremely efficient predators, as each of them must hunt hundreds of mosquito larvae (or comparable prey) before reaching adulthood.  Such efficient prey capture in an aquatic environment is very challenging for these larvae as their small size severely constrains their ability to detect and judge the distance of their prey.  In this project we investigated how the bizarre organization of the beetle larval eyes facilitates catching prey under such challenging conditions. Much can be gained from understanding such new optical and neural organizations, both to get valuable insights into fundamental biological phenomena, and to uncover design principles that are useful for engineering approaches.

         Our work revealed that the principal (main) eyes of diving beetle larvae (Figure 2) are characterized by a unique bifocal lens, and by an exceptional anatomical organization of the eye: a vitreous-like tissue assures that the larvae’s multiple retinas are precisely positioned behind the lens, while shaping the eye into a tube that enhances resolution.  Our data suggests that in addition to detecting green and UV light, larvae are also able to use polarized light to better detect their prey.  Through optical measurements we determined that a bifocal lens produces two sharp images (Figure 3), and that these images are precisely focused on specific photosensitive layers of their retinas.  By performing behavioral experiments we demonstrated that larvae use this information for a sophisticated distance estimation strategy.  Diving beetle larvae continue to be able to correctly assess how far away they are from their prey, even in circumstances under which other animals are unable to do so, as commonly used distance cues are unavailable to them.  We are very excited that these distance-estimation principles have already started to inform novel technologies. Specifically, a team of engineers already has built a Thermonectus-based prototype distance sensor, and we anticipate that our findings will guide additional future technologies.  Other technological advances include our development of a unique ophthalmoscope, which we use to give beetle larvae a vision test without harming them.  This setup is also suitable to measure eyes and image the retina of a wide variety of other invertebrates while they are alive, and will become an important more general tool for vision science.

      This project thus far has generated 10 peer-reviewed publications, which includes the publication of teaching materials for an undergraduate neurophysiology laboratory.  The research project was the basis of training eighteen undergraduate and seven graduate students as well as one post-doctoral researcher, and we used aspects of our science in a variety of outreach activities that demonstrated the importance of basic science to the general public.
